choices.text: The thymine nucleotide required for DNA synthesis
All of the pyrimidines required for RNA synthesis

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman at 32 weeks of gestation presents for her routine prenatal visit. She has a history of recurrent folate deficiencies. Her current blood work reveals macrocytic anemia. A deficiency in folate would most likely decrease the production of which of the following compounds?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. The thymine nucleotide required for DNA synthesis.

 

Option A.

 

The thymine nucleotides are required for DNA synthesis, and it is the only pyrimidine which requires folate for its synthesis (dUMP to dTMP).

 

dUMP → (dTMP) by thymidylate synthase, which uses N5, N10- methylene tetra hydro folate as the source of the methyl group.

 

Inhibitors of thymidylate synthase: Thymine analogs - 5-fluorouracil → converted to 5-fluoro deoxy uridine and DHF → reduced to THF by dihydrofolate reductase, an enzyme that is inhibited by folate analogs such as methotrexate.

 

By decreasing the supply of THF, these drugs inhibit purine synthesis and also decrease preventing the methylation of dUMP to dTMP.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Creatine phosphate from creatine: The synthesis of creatine phosphate from creatine is not directly related to folate metabolism and is unaffected by folate levels.

 

Option C. All of the pyrimidines required for RNA synthesis: While folate is involved in nucleotide synthesis, its deficiency primarily affects the production of thymine, not all pyrimidines.

 

Option D. Phosphatidylcholine from diacylglycerol and CDP-choline: The synthesis of phosphatidylcholine from diacylglycerol and CDP-choline is a part of lipid metabolism and is not dependent on folate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folate deficiency affects DNA synthesis, particularly the synthesis of thymine nucleotide. Folate is required for the production of tetrahydrofolate (THF), which acts as a carrier of one-carbon units necessary in various metabolic processes, including the methylation of deoxyuridylic acid (dUMP) to thymidylic acid (dTMP), a precursor of thymine nucleotide.

 

Ref: Lippincott 6/e:  p 303-304.

choices.text: Inhibit bacterial synthesis of THF
Block transport across bacterial cell walls
Inhibit bacterial synthesis of cobalamin (B12)
Bind to operons to prevent synthesis of bacterial mRNA

questions.text: 28-year-old female experiences recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) and initially receives lower-tier antibiotics, which prove ineffective. Subsequently, she is prescribed a combination therapy containing trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole, which successfully alleviates her symptoms. This combination is particularly effective due to its ability to disrupt a specific bacterial process. What is the mechanism by which trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole reduce UTI symptoms in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inhibit bacterial synthesis of THF

 

Option A.

 

Bacteria might synthesize the folate which is required for their biosynthetic processes, and they do not have a transporter to bring the folate into the cell.

 

Trimethoprim inhibits prokaryotic DHFR (eukaryotic is not affected) and sulfamethoxazole is an analog of p-aminobenzoic acid (PABA), a precursor to folic acid.

 

So, Bacteria will use this analog instead of PABA and produce a non-functional folate.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Block transport across bacterial cell walls: This mechanism is not how trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole work; it is more characteristic of antibiotics like beta-lactams.

 

Option C. Inhibit bacterial synthesis of cobalamin (B12): Neither trimethoprim nor sulfamethoxazole affects cobalamin synthesis in bacteria.

 

Option D. Bind to operons to prevent synthesis of bacterial mRNA: This description does not represent the action of trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole; these drugs specifically target folate synthesis, not mRNA synthesis directly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole block two critical steps in bacterial folate synthesis, crucial for DNA production and cell growth, reducing bacterial proliferation and UTI symptoms.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 353-354, 559.

choices.text: A and R both are right but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is wrong but R is a right statement
A as well as R are right and R is a correct explanation of A
A and R both are wrong

questions.text:
Assertion (A): In the transmethylation process, the conversion of homocysteine to methionine requires folate and vitamin B12 as cofactors.

 

Reasoning (R): The enzyme for this remethylation process is homocysteine methyltransferase, which requires a methyl group from methylcobalamin, which in turn, acquires the methyl group from methyl-THF (tetrahydrofolate).
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A as well as R are right and R is a correct explanation of A

 

Option C:

 

 

  • Homocysteine can be converted to methionine by addition of a methyl group from one-carbon pool with the help of vitamin B12.
  • Enzyme: Homocysteine methyltransferase

 

Educational objective:

 

The biochemical process of homocysteine remethylation to methionine, which requires the cofactors folate (in the form of methyl-THF) and vitamin B12 (as methylcobalamin), and is catalyzed by the enzyme methionine synthase. This pathway is crucial for methionine regeneration and overall methylation processes in the body.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 30 /e, p 559

questions.text: A medical team is discussing the treatment options for a patient with methotrexate toxicity, focusing on the supportive care required to mitigate the effects of the drug on folate metabolism. Which form of tetrahydrofolate (THFA) is utilized in the clinical management of such cases?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) N5 Formyl THFA

 

Option A:

 

N5 Formyl THFA, also known as leucovorin or folinic acid, is the form of THFA used in the clinical setting, particularly in the treatment of methotrexate toxicity or as a rescue agent after high-dose methotrexate therapy in cancer treatments. It bypasses the metabolic block caused by methotrexate, allowing for the continuation of vital cellular functions that depend on folate.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. N10 Formyl THFA: This form is involved in purine synthesis but is not typically used as a treatment form in the clinical setting.

 

Option C. N5 Formimino THFA: This form participates in the metabolism of histidine, but it is not used as a treatment in the context of folate metabolism disorders.

 

Option D. N5 Methyl THFA: Although important in the methionine cycle, it is not the form used to counteract the effects of methotrexate toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • 5 Formyl THFA is more stable than Folate, known as Folinic acid (used pharmaceutically).
  • The synthetic racemic compound of Folinic acid is Leucovorin.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 207.

questions.text: In a clinic specializing in nutritional deficiencies, a healthcare provider is reviewing a case where a patient present with an unusual increase in the excretion of FIGLU in the urine. The provider considers this finding in the context of potential vitamin deficiencies. Which deficiency is most likely responsible for the increased excretion of FIGLU?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Folic acid

 

Option B:

 

Histidine load test or FIGLU excretion test:

 

  • Histidine is normally metabolized to formimino glutamic acid (FIGLU) from which formimino group is removed by THFA.

 

 

  • Hence, in folate deficiency, FIGLU is excreted in urine.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Thiamine: Deficiency primarily affects energy metabolism and the nervous system but is not directly linked to increased urinary FIGLU.

 

Option C. Ascorbic acid: Vitamin C deficiency leads to scurvy, characterized by symptoms like bleeding gums and poor wound healing, not increased FIGLU excretion.

 

Option D. Nicotinic acid: Deficiency results in pellagra, involving dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, without a direct connection to FIGLU metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The excretion of FIGLU in the urine is indicative of a folic acid deficiency. FIGLU is an intermediate in the metabolism of the amino acid histidine. Normally, folic acid is required for the conversion of FIGLU to glutamate, and in the absence of adequate folic acid, FIGLU accumulates and is excreted in the urine.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 243.

questions.text: Neural tube defects such as anencephaly and spina bifida have higher frequencies in certain populations. Which of the following vitamins is associated with the occurrence of neural tube defects (anencephaly and spina bifida)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Folic acid

 

Option D:

 

  • It is necessary for the development of the neural tube in the first few weeks of embryonic life and the children of women with nutritional deficiencies have higher rates of NTDs.
  • It is essential that all women of childbearing age take a folic acid supplement of approximately 0.4mg/ day.
  • Folic acid deficiency can cause megaloblastic anemia due to decreased synthesis of the purines and pyrimidines needed for cells to make DNA and divide

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ascorbic acid: Deficiency leads to scurvy, which causes bleeding gums and bone disease.

 

Option B. Thiamine: Deficiency from excess of polished rice can cause beriberi and in chronic alcoholics cause Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which is characterized by loss of memory, lackadaisical behaviour, and a continuous rhythmic movement of the eyeballs.

 

Option C. Riboflavin: Deficiency leads to mouth ulcers (stomatitis), cheilosis (dry, scaly lips), scaly skin (seborrhoea) and photophobia.

 

Educational objective:

 

Folic acid, or folate, is crucial for proper neural tube development during early pregnancy. Deficiencies in folic acid around the time of conception and during early pregnancy are strongly associated with an increased risk of neural tube defects, including anencephaly and spina bifida. This is why folic acid supplementation is widely recommended for women of childbearing age.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan  9/e: p 489

choices.text: Increased requirement of folate by drugs
Drug action along with dietary intake
Inhibition of folate absorption by inhibiting intestinal enzyme

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of epilepsy, treated with phenytoin and barbiturates, presents with fatigue and difficulty performing daily activities. She appears pale, and blood tests reveal deficiencies in vitamin B12 and folic acid, with megaloblastic changes in a peripheral blood smear and a positive FIGLU test in urine. What is the mechanism by which her anticonvulsant medications contribute to her folic acid deficiency?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inhibition of folate absorption by inhibiting intestinal enzyme

 

Option C:

 

  • In the diet, folacins are in polyglutamate form.
  • Gastrointestinal enzymes remove the glutamate residues and only the remaining mono-glutamate form of folic acid is absorbed.
  • Anticonvulsant drugs such as hydantoin, dilantin, phenytoin, phenobarbitone causes inhibition of the intestinal enzyme → reduced folate absorption.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Increased requirement of folate by drugs: While some conditions or treatments may increase the body's need for folate, anticonvulsant drugs primarily cause folate deficiency through interference with its absorption rather than increasing the body's folate requirements.

 

Option B. Drug action along with dietary intake: This option is too vague and doesn't directly explain the mechanism by which these drugs cause folate deficiency.

 

 

Option D. Causing folate trap: The folate trap is a specific mechanism related to vitamin B12 deficiency and the improper conversion of folate forms within the body. It's not directly related to the action of anticonvulsant drugs on folate status.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anticonvulsant drugs, such as phenytoin and barbiturates, can lead to folic acid deficiency by inhibiting the enzymes required for its intestinal absorption. Recognizing drug-nutrient interactions is essential for managing the holistic health of patients on long-term medication regimens, especially those with conditions requiring anticonvulsants.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 489.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of rheumatoid arthritis has been receiving methotrexate therapy. Recently, she presented with symptoms of methotrexate toxicity, including stomatitis, leukopenia, and gastrointestinal distress. The medical team plans to administer an antidote to counteract these adverse effects. Which agent is most appropriate for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leucovorin

 

Option B:

 

Leucovorin (folinic acid) is used to treat methotrexate toxicity. It acts as a folate analog that can bypass dihydrofolate reductase inhibition by methotrexate, allowing for the continuation of DNA synthesis and cellular repair processes. This makes it an effective antidote for reducing the toxic effects of methotrexate.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aminopterin: Like methotrexate, aminopterin is a folate antagonist and would exacerbate, rather than mitigate, the toxic effects of methotrexate.

 

Option C. Thiamine: Thiamine (Vitamin B1) is important for energy metabolism but does not play a role in counteracting methotrexate toxicity.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12: While Vitamin B12 is crucial for various bodily functions, including DNA synthesis, it does not serve as an antidote to methotrexate toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aminopterin (4-amino folic acid) and amethopterin (methotrexate) (4-amino, 10-methyl folic acid) are competitive inhibitors of folate reductase and THFA generation. Hence, these drugs decrease the DNA formation and cell division. They are used as anticancer drugs (antimetabolites) for leukemias and choriocarcinomas.
  • Folinic acid (citrovorum factor) is used to treat the patient with methotrexate toxicity. Methotrexate is also used in treatment of rheumatoid arthritis as an immunosuppressant.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 491.

questions.text: A clinical nutritionist is explaining the importance of various micronutrients in metabolic pathways to a group of medical students. One topic of discussion is the biochemical process involving the transfer of one-carbon units, which is crucial for DNA synthesis and amino acid metabolism. The nutritionist emphasizes the role of a specific vitamin in this process. Which vitamin is essential for the transfer of one-carbon units?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Folic acid

 

Option B:

 

  • The THFA is the carrier of one-carbon groups.
  • One carbon compound is an organic molecule which contains only a single carbon atom.
  • The following one carbon compounds:
    • Formyl (-CHO)
    • Formimino (-CH=NH)
    • Methenyl (-CH=)
    • Methylene (-CH2–)
    • Hydroxymethyl (-CH2OH)
    • Methyl (-CH3).
  • They get attached either to the 5th or 10th or to both 5th and 10th nitrogen atoms of THFA.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Retinol: Also known as vitamin A, retinol is crucial for vision, immune function, and skin health, but it does not play a direct role in the transfer of one-carbon units.

 

Option C. Niacin: While essential for energy metabolism, niacin (vitamin B3) is not directly involved in the transfer of one-carbon units.

 

Option D. Riboflavin: Vitamin B2 is vital for energy production and the metabolism of fats, drugs, and steroids, but it is not directly involved in one-carbon metabolism like folic acid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folic acid plays a central role in the transfer of one-carbon units, a process vital for the synthesis of nucleotides (DNA and RNA synthesis) and the metabolism of certain amino acids. Folic acid and its derivatives, such as tetrahydrofolate (THF), act as carriers of methyl, formyl, and methenyl groups in various biochemical reactions.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 489.

questions.text: In a discussion on the role of nutrition in cancer prevention, a clinical researcher presents a hypothesis on dietary factors influencing colorectal cancer risk. Considering the importance of micronutrients in cellular processes, which vitamin's low status is suggested to potentially increase the risk of developing colorectal cancer due to its critical role in DNA synthesis and repair?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Folic acid

 

Option D:

 

Folic acid (vitamin B9) is essential for DNA synthesis and repair. Low levels of folic acid can lead to DNA damage, potentially increasing the risk of mutations and the development of colorectal cancer. Epidemiological studies have suggested an association between low folic acid status and an increased risk of colorectal cancer, highlighting the importance of adequate folic acid intake in cancer prevention.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: While important for vision and immune function, vitamin A's deficiency has not been directly linked to an increased risk of colorectal cancer.

 

Option B. Vitamin B12: Essential for nerve function and the formation of red blood cells, vitamin B12 deficiency is more commonly associated with anemia and neurological issues than with colorectal cancer risk.

 

Option C. Vitamin C: Known for its antioxidant properties, vitamin C plays a role in preventing oxidative stress. While important for overall health, its direct association with colorectal cancer risk due to deficiency is less clear than that of folic acid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folic acid and cancer

 

  • Low folate status would result in impaired methylation of CpG islands in DNA, which is a factor for the development of colorectal and other cancers.
  • Prophylactic doses of Folic Acid during pregnancy reduces the chances of Acute Lymphoblastic Lymphoma.
  • Also folate supplements increase the rate of transformation of pre neoplastic colorectal polyps into cancers by increasing thymidine pools and improved quality DNA.
  • Hence, Folic Acid should be avoided in established tumors.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 490.
